Award.AbstractNarration:
A central goal of democracy is to achieve a disburse distribution of power. Participatory and representative institutions of government are designed with that goal in mind. And yet, a major theme of political discourse is the high and persistent degree of concentrated political power that emerges in democratic governments across space and time. The tendency for political power to concentrate is evidently difficult to control. This research investigates why political power concentrates. The investigators shall develop a framework and tools that offer clear strategic intuitions for how key players capture and control political processes, exploiting information about who has power in the future, and offering amendments contingent on previous voting decisions. Their framework launches a broader research agenda on identifying when information, transparency, and flexibility exacerbate the inequality of political and economic power.

The investigators propose two models of dynamic political institutions. The first is a framework of negotiations and policymaking where players have information about which players have agenda-setting power in the future. They find that transparency can exacerbate inequality and inefficiency. The second project is a framework of a flexible agenda-setter who cannot vote on outcomes but can make proposals to a voting body. The investigators find that even when voters are far-sighted and sophisticated, an agenda setter can manipulate the voting body by flexibly offering amendments that are contingent on the voting outcome.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has had a broader impact across three principal dimensions. The first impact is in our understanding of public policy and political processes. Understanding why and how political power concentrates in democracies, and designing institutional safeguards to prevent a democracy from becoming a dictatorship or oligarchy are important pursuits of political economy. Our research highlights how features that are intuitively appealing---such as flexibility and information about transitions in power---may perversely lead to greater concentration of power. Similarly, our research raises the concern that procedural constraints that indicate a fairer political process may lead to more unequal outcomes. These insights are useful for both our understanding of U.S. politics and the design of political institutions for new democracies. 
Second, the research involves running a simple laboratory experiment that tests some basic principles of coalition formation, alongside the implications of predictability. We view our designs as being useful for substantive research in this area, especially for those that wish to understand the implications of information, social preferences, or test for history-dependent behavior in coalition formation. We will make our data available for subsequent analysis and comparison to other majoritarian bargaining experiments. 

Our major publication is "Predictability and Power in Legislative Bargaining," published in 2019 in the Review of Economic Studies and available here:

doi:10.1093/restud/rdy013
